awd_titl_txt: New Color Centers in Diamond: Towards Broadband Quantum Memories
awd_abstract_narration:
Information technologies are among the main pillars of society, and information security is becoming more important. One direction for improving the security of future information systems is to utilize quantum communication lines. Based on laws of nature, such lines do not allow non-traceable copying of the information transmitted. But the same physics that makes them secure (i.e. the non-cloning theorem) also forbids the use of classical repeaters, which in turn limits communication distance and speed. This issue may be overcome by using quantum repeaters, the key ingredient of which is a quantum memory device.  The aim of this project is to develop a novel solid-state quantum memory based on quantum states of color centers in diamond.  This project will utilize theoretical and experimental advances developed at Texas A&M University both for the memory access protocol and for its physical implementation.  This research project will strengthen the US presence in the field of optical ensemble-based solid-state quantum memories. It will also help train the next generation of scientists in this dynamically developing interdisciplinary field of research. Graduate and undergraduate students will get involved in the investigations through participation in the experiments, developing theoretical models, programming, collecting and interpreting experimental data, and numerical simulations. The investigators will also incorporate the obtained results into courses.

This project focuses on new color centers, namely, Germanium Vacancies and Silicon Vacancies in diamond (GeV and SiV) for pioneering experimental realization of an ensemble based broadband quantum memory in diamond. This realization will be achieved using a new approach to quantum memory based on a discrete spatial chirp of a control field that has recently been suggested by the co-PIs. The outcome of this work, a single-photon solid-state interface, will be a milestone on the way to a scalable universal optical quantum computer. In comparison to existing technologies, like rare-earth doped crystals and nitrogen vacancy centers in diamond (NV), SiV and GeV have stronger optical interaction and less spectral diffusion (and inhomogeneous linewidths). The stronger zero-phonon line gives more efficient interaction of a single photon with a single silicon-vacancy, while a narrow inhomogeneous line broadening favors ensemble-based quantum memories. Other advantages of GeV and SiV are the presence of polarization selection rules and large (160 GHz and 50 GHz accordingly) energy level splitting in the ground state. The last one allows for large storage bandwidth. It is worth pointing out that multi-GHz vs MHz bandwidth is a key advantage of an optical over RF quantum networks (i.e. superconducting circuits (SCC)). The only disadvantage of GeV and SiV is a shorter electron-spin coherence time. However, it has been shown that this can be dramatically increased, up to 13 ms, by cooling SiV down to 100 mK.

por.por_cntn:
The project aimed at theoretical and experimental studies of the new techniques as well as new solid materials for realization of fast quantum memory, based on an ensemble-of color centers in diamond. Such a memory would provide mapping of the quantum state of a photon into a collective state of the quantum emitters and retrieval this state on demand.

Intellectual Merit

The new scheme for quantum storage based on a spatial frequency chirp of a control field as well as its analog for realization of the nuclear quantum memory via a set of moving solids with different velocities resonant nuclear absorbers were proposed. This scheme includes illumination of the sample in the direction orthogonal to the direction of the single photon propagation by multiple beams derived from the control fields with equidistantly increasing frequencies. Such a chain of control pulses leads to multiple electromagnetically induced transparency (EIT) resonances, covering large range of spectral components of the signal pulse and thus allowing broadband memory realization. Ensembles of fluorescent color centers with inversion center symmetry (Ge, Si, Sn) in diamond, and 57Fe nuclei in other crystals or alloys have been identified as promising materials for realization of such broad-band (1-100 MHz range) quantum memories in the optical and hard x-ray ranges, respectively.

Narrow EIT-like two-photon resonances in an ensemble of the Ge vacancies in diamond were demonstrated for the first time. The physical origin of the observed resonances, as an overlap of the narrow transparency dips formed by Autler-Townes splitting of the sub-ensembles forming a total inhomogenously broadened ensemble was established. This physical origin likely also applies to EIT-like resonances observed in many prior papers. Optical characteristic of the ensembles of Ge vacancies in diamond were determined and the possibility to use Ge vacancies as the quantum sensors of temperature was demonstrated experimentally.

A unique design for a Gallium Phosphide nanobeam cavity with ${Q/V} > {10^8}$, a small footprint, and a high cooperativity, ${10^5}$ has been developed. Silicon nitride offers less impressive performance characteristics than gallium phosphide, but it is more nanofab friendly, and a more robust widely used material. To implement this design, fabrication and characterization of nanobeam photonic crystal cavities based on silicon nitride at visible wavelengths was accomplished. To characterize this device in detail light was coupled from optical fibers to on-chip suspended Si3N4 nanobeam photonic crystal cavities with a coupling efficiency of 96(2)%, which is high enough for the realization of the integrated quantum network platform. The fabricated device offers a promising platform for strong coupling in solid-state cavity QED experiments and realization of quantum memory with suppressed quantum noise.

These results will facilitate further development of quantum memories, quantum sensors, photonic nano-crystal cavities and on chip integrated quantum networks.

Broader impact

Development of the broad band quantum memories, photonic nano-crystal cavities and efficient cavity-fiber couplers is necessary for realization of the solid-state platform for the long-distance quantum communication, quantum computing, integrated quantum photonic network and quantum internet, which would greatly facilitate communication and computation.

The photonic crystal cavities with high quality factor could be used in many fields of photonics, as well as in the field of optomechanics.

The Ge vacancy and Sn vacancy in diamond demonstrated as quantum sensors of temperature and magnetic field are expected to find wide applications in biology and medicine.

The project provided training of young people (students and postdocs, including researchers from the minority groups) in a strategically important field of quantum technologies. It provided numerous opportunities for research experience in the fields of quantum information and material sciences for the young researchers (4 graduate students, 3 undergraduate students, including one female student and 4 postdocs, including two female postdocs). Three graduate students were trained in experimental quantum optics. They participated in setting up low temperature experiments, designing and implementing of the optical part of the experiment, collecting experimental data, designing, and implementing photonic crystal cavities, interpreting and processing the data collected. One graduate student advanced his skills in theoretical quantum optics, participating in theoretical modeling, analytical techniques, programming. All young researchers learnt to work together as a team, including a close collaboration between the experimental and theoretical groups allowing to develop a thorough understanding of the experimental results as well as the theoretical issues involved. One student successfully graduated with MS degree and two with PhD degree.
